Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Lidar and Sonar Surveys of a Dune Reinforced with Geotextile Sand Containers Impacted by Tropical Storm Hermine

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy in 2012 on the northeast United States highlighted the need to improve the ability of coastal communities to quickly respond and rebound from natural hazards. There is a trend towards implementing "soft" engineering solutions such as dunes reinforced with Geotextile Sand Containers (GSC) to improve resiliency rather than traditional hardened structures like stone revetments. These have the potential to protect communities from smaller storm events (e.g. 25-year storms) while at the same time providing flexibility in design considering the uncertainty regarding rates of sea level rise and storm frequency. "Soft" engineering solutions may also be less disruptive to the natural morphology of barrier beach systems than hardened structures. However, there is still considerable uncertainty regarding the mechanisms that affect the stability of reinforced dunes under wave attack. The objective of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project is to collect perishable data to assess the stability and performance of a 1000 m section of a dune reinforced with GSCs in Montauk, NY that was impacted by Tropical Storm Hermine in September 2016. The reinforced dune was constructed in March 2016, and Tropical Storm Hermine resulted in complete erosion of the protective berm, exposure of the GSC core, and movement of the lower level of GSCs.

A detailed 3-D digital elevation model of both the eroded beach (topography) as well as the near-shore bathymetry will be constructed. This will be accomplished through two surveys: an aerial LIDAR survey using an Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) and a combined ship-mounted LIDAR and interferometric sonar system. These data will provide a detailed case study of the effects of wave action on a dune reinforced with GSCs. This will allow for the application of findings from numerical and wave flume studies to an actual field case at a scale not reproducible in the laboratory. It is hypothesized that current stability equations are unconservative in that they underpredict the hydraulic stability of geotextile containers associated with reduced scale experiments. Analysis of this case study will also improve our understanding of whether reinforced dunes perform as "soft" coastal structures and do not significantly modify the natural morphology of the shoreline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increased coastal erosion rates have forced communities to rethink how to manage vulnerable coastlines. Nature-based systems, such as Geotextile Sand Containers (GSCs) and geo-tubes, have been used for decades in emergency or temporary applications to stabilize erosion hot spots and ?buy time? for communities while long-term solutions are developed. More recently, however, there is an appreciation that these applications, particularly when covered or used as the core of a dune, may provide protection for longer periods. Despite this, there is still considerable uncertainty regarding the mechanisms that affect the stability of reinforced dunes under wave attack, their performance over many years, and recognized design standards.

In March 2016, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) New York District completed the first federal project to reconstruct dunes stabilized with GSCs in Montauk, NY as a short-term (15-year design life) stabilization measure while long term alternatives are being assessed. Within a few months of completion, Tropical Storm Hermine caused significant erosion of the beach and exposed sections of the GSC core. Since then, the performance of the Montauk reinforced dune has been monitored as part of a RAPID grant for collecting perishable data. The monitoring program includes the use of interferometric sonar for nearshore bathymetry, Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) GPS, and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) with ?structure from motion? photogrammetry to develop digital elevation models (DEMs) before and after storm events. To date, thirteen surveys of damage, beach erosion and accretion, and replenishment have been performed before and after storm events. Information from these surveys has been used to calibrate a 2-D erosion model using the hydro-morphodynamic software package XBeach, and this model is currently being used to develop fragility curves for various damage states associated with GSC-reinforced dunes.

As expected, the GSC core of the reinforced dune has remained intact and there has been no significant movement of individual GSCs. However, there has been significant erosion of the beach and protective berm, resulting in periodic exposure of sections of the GSC core. This has resulted in at least three beach replenishment programs, which was not anticipated in the design process. This monitoring supports the idea that periodic replenishment and reshaping are a required element (and thus part of the life-cycle cost) of these nature-based systems.

The intellectual merits of this study are 1.) a detailed case study of the on-going performance of the first federally-funded GSC-reinforced dune from the initial construction throughout its design life, 2.) identification of damage states for the development of fragility curves for reinforced dunes, and 3.) a calibrated, 2-D erosion model of 1000m long site using the program XBeach.

The results of this project have the potential to improve our understanding of the performance of nature-based coastal protection systems over longer time periods, which will help decision makers prioritize similar stabilization projects if critical infrastructure becomes imminently threatened during a significant weather event. While a reinforced natural system may not be the preferred community option when compared to a large-scale beach nourishment project, limited funding availability and the timeline associated with a typical design-permit-construct nourishment project may force more communities to select similar nature-based systems to stabilize their coastlines if retreat is not an option at the current time.
